text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily
News \-- A new study on Environmental Pollution is now available. According to
news originating from Tamil Nadu, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research
stated, "In the last few decades, consciousness of fossil fuel resources and
increased environmental concerns have given the need for emergence of
alternative fuel. Biodiesel is one of the potential renewable energies
produced from edible and non-edible biomass which could be a potential
alternative for petrol-derived diesel."

Financial support for this research came from Council of Scientific &
Industrial Research, India.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Anna University,
"In this work, initially the process of biodiesel production from waste
cooking oil using potassium hydroxide as catalyst and the process parameters
were studied in laboratory. The maximum biodiesel yield of 97% was attained at
75 degrees C with 1 wt% catalyst concentration and oil-methanol molar ratio of
1:06 at 350 rpm and 90 min. Also, these process conditions were used for
biodiesel production in the pilot plant and obtained 97% yield. Overall, mass
balance for the pilot plant was studied to analyze the product yield loss. The
fatty acid methyl ester formation in the plant was confirmed by
characterization with FTIR and H-1 NMR."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Further, the quality
of biodiesel produced was compared for its physiochemical properties with the
ASTM standards."

For more information on this research see: Feasibility of Biodiesel Production
From Waste Cooking Oil: Lab-scale To Pilot-scale Analysis. _Environmental
Science and Pollution Research_ , 2020;():. _Environmental Science and
Pollution Research_ can be contacted at: Springer Heidelberg,
Tiergartenstrasse 17, D-69121 Heidelberg, Germany. (Springer -
[www.springer.com](http://www.springer.com); Environmental Science and
Pollution Research \- <http://www.springerlink.com/content/0944-1344/>)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from K. Devaraj, Anna University, Alagappa College of Technology, Dept. of
Applied Sciences and Technologies, Chennai 600025, Tamil Nadu, India.
Additional authors for this research include Y. Mani, S.A.A. Rawoof, A.
Thanarasu, S. Subramanian and A. Dhanasekaran.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1007/s11356-020-09068-6>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Environmental Pollution Study Findings Reported from Anna University (Feasibility of Biodiesel Production From Waste Cooking Oil: Lab-scale To Pilot-scale Analysis): Environmental Pollution
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- A new study on Environmental Pollution is now available. According to news originating from Tamil Nadu, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “In the last few decades, consciousness of fossil fuel resources and increased environmental concerns have given the need for emergence of alternative fuel. Biodiesel is one of the potential renewable energies produced from edible and non-edible biomass which could be a potential alternative for petrol-derived diesel.”

Financial support for this research came from Council of Scientific & Industrial Research, India.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Anna University, “In this work, initially the process of biodiesel production from waste cooking oil using potassium hydroxide as catalyst and the process parameters were studied in laboratory. The maximum biodiesel yield of 97% was attained at 75 degrees C with 1 wt% catalyst concentration and oil-methanol molar ratio of 1:06 at 350 rpm and 90 min. Also, these process conditions were used for biodiesel production in the pilot plant and obtained 97% yield. Overall, mass balance for the pilot plant was studied to analyze the product yield loss. The fatty acid methyl ester formation in the plant was confirmed by characterization with FTIR and H-1 NMR.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Further, the quality of biodiesel produced was compared for its physiochemical properties with the ASTM standards.”

For more information on this research see: Feasibility of Biodiesel Production From Waste Cooking Oil: Lab-scale To Pilot-scale Analysis. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 2020;():. Environmental Science and Pollution Research can be contacted at: Springer Heidelberg, Tiergartenstrasse 17, D-69121 Heidelberg, Germany. (Springer - www.springer.com; Environmental Science and Pollution Research - http://www.springerlink.com/content/0944-1344/)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from K. Devaraj, Anna University, Alagappa College of Technology, Dept. of Applied Sciences and Technologies, Chennai 600025, Tamil Nadu, India. Additional authors for this research include Y. Mani, S.A.A. Rawoof, A. Thanarasu, S. Subramanian and A. Dhanasekaran.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11356-020-09068-6. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
